question: Question_C_05_2
statement:
Choose ONE of the next two problems (C.5.1 or C.5.2).

An architect is designing a house in the form of a cylinder covered by a
roof in the shape of half a sphere (extending above the cylinder).
Suppose the material used to build the cylindrical wall is half the
price of the material that is used to build the roof per unit area. If
the total volume of the house is fixed, what ratio between the height of
the wall and the radius of the roof will minimize the cost?
sols:
Let's start with a picture.

\begin{figure}[htbp]
\centering
\includegraphics[width=.5\textwidth]{MER_Math_102_December_2012_Question_C_5_2_Solution.jpg}
\caption{MER Math 102 December 2012 Question C 5 2 Solution.jpg}
\end{figure}

Let \emph{P} be the price of the wall material per square area. Thus,
the price of the roof is \emph{2P} per square area. Let \emph{V} be the
given volume. The formula for the volume of this house is

$V = \pi r^{2} h + \frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{4}{3} \pi r^{3}\right) = \pi r^{2} \left(h + \frac{2r}{3} \right)$

where the first term is the volume of a cylinder and the second term is
half the volume of a sphere. We will need to isolate for \emph{h} later
so doing so now while the formula is fresh, we have

$h = \frac{V}{\pi r^{2}} - \frac{2r}{3}$

We're minimizing the cost of the house. The cost of this house is equal
to the surface area of the wall multiplied by the price added to the
surface area of the roof multiplied by \emph{2P}. As part of our
simplification process, we'll plug in the formula for \emph{h}
immediately above, to arrive at a final equation that's only in terms of
one variable, \emph{r}.

\begin{align*}
C &= 2\pi rhP + 0.5(4\pi r^{2})(2P) \\
&= 2\pi rP(h + 2r)\\
&= 2\pi rP\left(\frac{V}{\pi r^{2}} - \frac{2r}{3} + 2r \right)\\
&= 2\pi rP\left(\frac{V}{\pi r^{2}} + \frac{4r}{3} \right)\end{align*}

Following our usual procedure for optimization, we take the derivative
by the product rule. Recall that \emph{V} and \emph{P} are constants -
our only variable is \emph{r}.

\begin{align*}
C' &= 2\pi P\left( \left(\frac{V}{\pi r^{2}} + \frac{4r}{3}\right) + r\left(\frac{-2V}{\pi r^{3}} + \frac{4}{3}\right) \right)\\
&= 2\pi P\left( \left(\frac{V}{\pi r^{2}} + \frac{4r}{3}\right) + \left(\frac{-2V}{\pi r^{2}} + \frac{4r}{3}\right) \right)\end{align*}

This is where we'll replace \emph{V} with our original volume formula
above, and simplify.

\begin{align*}
C' &= 2\pi P\left( \left(h + \frac{2r}{3} + \frac{4r}{3}\right) + \left(-2\left(h + \frac{2r}{3}\right) + \frac{4r}{3}\right) \right)\\
&= 2\pi P\left( \left(h + 2r\right) + \left(-2h\right) \right)\\
&= 2\pi P(2r-h)\end{align*}

Setting the derivative to zero and solving gives
$\frac{r}{h} = \frac{1}{2}$. One more subtlety with this problem is that
we should verify that this is indeed a minimum. Plugging back in terms
of \emph{r} in the first derivative gives

\begin{align*}
C' &= 2\pi P(2r-h)\\
&= 2\pi P(2r-(V/(\pi r^{2}) - 2r/3))\\
&= 2\pi P(8r/3 - V/(\pi r^{2}))\\
&= 2\pi P((8\pi r^{3} - 3V)/(3\pi r^{2}))\end{align*}

Setting to zero and solving gives $r^{3} = 3V/(8\pi) > 0$ (notice that
\emph{r} equal 0 is not admissible since our house needs a radius, so we
don't need to worry about this critical point). Taking the second
derivative yields

\begin{align*}
C'' &= 8/3 + \frac{2V}{\pi r^{3}}\end{align*}

and since \emph{r} is positive in our critical value, we see that our
second derivative is positive, hence our cost function is concave up and
thus this ratio of \emph{r} to \emph{h} is a minimum as required.
hints:
Draw a picture. Find a formula expressing the volume of the house in
terms of \emph{r} and \emph{h}. Then find a formula for the cost of the
house in terms of \emph{r}, \emph{h}, and \emph{P}. Which formula are
you optimizing? What is the next step when solving optimization
problems?

In this problem, you are optimizing the cost function. Before taking the
derivative, you will need to reduce this equation from two variables
(\emph{r} and \emph{h}) to one (\emph{r}). To do so, solve the volume
equation for \emph{h} and substitute it into your cost function.

After taking the derivative, set it equal to zero. Normally you would
now solve for critical points - however, this question is asking for a
ratio, not a single value. In order to find this ratio, you'll have to
re-introduce the variable \emph{h} into the derivative by substituting
the volume formula in for \emph{V}.
